paragraphs.text: This is the first time I hear about Mr. Kabat-Zinn. Who coined him the father of mindfulness? Does not meditation and mindfulness originate in yoga, which predates even Buddha (he himself learned meditation from Hindu tradition)?

paragraphs.text: A wonderful article but I really would challenge that term the father of mindfulness and having met the man a few times I think he would too, he even acknowledges this in the article by saying that mindfulness is at the heart of Buddhist thinking philosophy and psychology and is this a practice of over 2,500 yrs from the experiences of Siddartha…

paragraphs.text: Reading this article helps one realizing oneself thoroughly to lead an undisturbed and stress free life. Being a teacher to adult student group I often insist them about realizing oneself, befriending oneself, self trust, self motivation etc… I also believe that suffering is needed in life as it burnishes us to estimate our own talent and tolerance…

paragraphs.name: ee46
paragraphs.text: A wonderful way to keep the “spiritual” in the mind, body, spirit — and without judging the “mcmindfulness” of it all . In 2016, there were 667 published research articles on mindfulness — in 2006 there were 47. The increase in mindfulness supply is in direct response to the rise of personal technology, yes, and perhaps also to the increasing demands…

paragraphs.name: fcd7
paragraphs.text: With all respect to the concerns that meditation can cause issues with certain psychological conditions, the research I’ve seen suggests the mindfulness training in those cases was very intensive, including days or weeks of complete immersion. But, just like beginning a physical exercise program, if you have issues, get counsel before getting on that bike.

paragraphs.text: No question re: the value of “mindfulness” (aka, meditative practice). But aren’t there also indications that this otherwise powerful ‘tool’ may actually be “counter-productive” for certain folks, especially those with mental and behavioral issues, and a ‘disordered’ ’ sense of Self and Ego to begin with? And even the Dalai Lama and other Buddhist…

content.subtitle: From the father of mindfulness himself.

paragraphs.name: ce48
paragraphs.text: JKZ: One of the byproducts of rapid spread of dharma wisdom in the world is that people will latch onto anything that’s hot and try to make a buck off of it, use it for advertising purposes to sell more jewelry or hamburgers. That’s not necessarily entirely bad. It’s a sign that [mindfulness] is actually going through society.

JKZ: [Mindfulness represents] a new way of being in relationship with yourself, one that’s catalytic of a new way of ongoing learning and healing. The transformation comes with the understanding that you are not your thoughts about yourself. You are far far bigger, more nuanced and multidimensional than who you think you are, the story of you.
